content.html:
“Good job!” said Uncle Berry.

“If you change the order of the elements in the phrase, you just have to change the order of the numbers in the ratio. Just make sure that the order of the elements in the phrase always matches the order of the numbers in the ratio.”

James loved the smoothies he made yesterday with Uncle Berry! He wanted to make some mango smoothies by himself, using the ratios from the “Smoothies for Kids” recipe book.

 

You should know the following before going on:

  • What a "ratio" is

  • How to write ratios using a colon, e.g. “2:3”.

Also, before starting, get some paper and a pen or pencil to write with, and find a quiet place to work. Take your time and go through the story at your own pace. If you get a question wrong, read the explanation carefully and try to understand the mistake, so that you can fix it.

Once you’re ready, click Continue to get started!

content.html:
“Uncle Berry, I have a question,” said James.

“Asking questions is good!" said Uncle Berry. "What is your question?”

“Well," said James, "this recipe says 'The ratio of blueberry puree to strawberry puree is 1:3.' But, if I want to say 'The ratio of strawberry puree to blueberry puree ...' instead, what do I do?"

“Excellent question," said Uncle Berry, "I think you can figure that one out. What do you think you should say?”

feedback.html: Yes, that is correct!

No, that is wrong. Read the question carefully, and try again. You may want to write out the ratio and the items clearly on a piece of paper, so you can see what corresponds to what.

content.html:
“Very good!” said Uncle Berry, “I think, after all that, we deserve a smoothie now!"

James looked through the recipe book, and found a different mixed-fruit smoothie. “Let’s make this one!” he said.

“All right," said Uncle Berry. "Before we start making a smoothie with this recipe, maybe you can figure out one more thing! This recipe says 'Mix blueberry puree, strawberry puree, banana puree, and milk in the ratio of 3:4:2:5.' How would you write the ratio of banana puree to blueberry puree to strawberry puree?"

feedback.html: Well done! You've remembered that you don't need to include information that the question doesn't ask for.

Here's a slightly trickier question.

To make a mixed fruit smoothie, we need milk, mango puree, blueberry puree and strawberry puree, as in the picture.

 

Write down the ratio of milk to blueberry puree to strawberry puree.

Let's try just one more!

A recipe tells us that the ratio of blueberry puree to milk is 1:2. Which of the following statements are true?

No, that is incorrect. People don't use the word 'and' when talking about ratios.

Let's go back just a little bit, to an earlier question. Pay close attention to how the ratio is described.

Let's practice this skill a bit more, since it's quite important.

content.html:
“Good job!” Uncle Berry gave James a thumbs up.

“Let’s remake the mango smoothie using the correct ratio,” suggested Uncle Berry. He looked at James. "Could you remind me what the ratio of the ingredients for the mango smoothie is?”

Confidently, James said, “The ratio of the ingredients is 1:2 ...” -- and then he stopped, thought a little, and added, “where 1 represents milk, and 2 represents mango puree.”

“Haha,” Uncle Berry looked at James, smiling. “Well done on trying to clarify which ingredients are represented by 1 and 2! But there's a shorter way to do that.”

What is a shorter way to correctly state the ratio of ingredients needed for the mango smoothie?

content.html:
Let’s try another one.

Write down the ratio of milk to blueberry puree to mango puree in the picture.

Uncle Berry walked into the kitchen. James explained that he had mixed a 1:2 ratio of milk and mango puree by using 1 cup of mango puree and 2 cups of milk.

"James," said Uncle Berry, "the order of elements listed in a phrase and the order of the numbers in a ratio need to be the same. When we say 'The ratio of milk to mango puree is 1:2', since milk comes first in the phrase, and 1 comes first in the ratio, 1 represents the relative amount of milk. Similarly, 2 represents the relative amount of mango puree.”

“On the other hand, when we say 'The ratio of mango puree to milk is 1:2', 1 represents mango puree and 2 represents milk."

“So, you need to always be aware of the order of the numbers given in the ratio,” said Uncle Berry.

“Got it!” said James.

In the ratio, 3 is written first, and 7 is written second.

It might be clearer if you write it like this:

Milk  :   Strawberry Puree

   3    :               7

So, what does the 3 represent?

No, that is wrong. Remember that a ratio does not show the exact amount of an item. Instead, it shows the relative amount of an item compared to other items.

content.html:
“Good job, James!" said Uncle Berry. "So, for this recipe, we can say ‘The ratio of milk to mango puree is 1:2'."

"Now, why don't you try writing the whole phrase by yourself? Write the ratio that the picture represents, clearly showing which number represents which element. Be sure to write it as 'the ratio of _________ puree to ________ puree is X:Y'."

explanation.html:
Let's write the ratio like this

blueberry puree :           milk           : banana puree : dark chocolate

            2              :              5             :              6           :            1

Keeping the item together with its corresponding number, we can change the order to what the question asks for. The result looks like this:

 blueberry puree : dark chocolate :          milk          : banana puree

            2               :              1             :             5             :             6

So, the answer is 2:1:5:6.

feedback.html: Excellent! You are doing great!

No, your answer is incorrect. Be careful with the order of the numbers.

Try again.
No, that is not correct. Try again.

blueberry puree : dark chocolate :          milk          : banana puree

          ?                :               ?             :              ?           :            ?

content.html:
“Good job! Do you want a trickier question?” asked Uncle Berry.

“Sure!" said James.

Uncle Berry said, “OK, then, try this one. If the ratio of blueberry puree to milk to banana puree to dark chocolate is 2:5:6:1, what is the ratio of blueberry puree to dark chocolate to milk to banana puree?"

James and Uncle Berry made a mixed-fruit smoothie with the recipe James chose. The smoothie was great! Now that he knows what ratios are and how to read them, James can make smoothies by himself.

Also, James made sure to remember some important things he learned. You might want to write them down, so that you remember too!

  • The order of the numbers in a ratio is important. When writing a ratio, we need to clearly state which number represents which element. For example: "The ratio of blueberry puree to strawberry puree is 2:3."

  • If we're given a ratio, we can easily use it to calculate the ratio for the same objects arranged in a different order.

strawberry puree : banana puree : blueberry puree

It says to put milk and mango in the ratio of 1:2

content.html:
James really enjoyed the mixed fruit smoothie that he made the day before. This time, though, he wanted to make a smoothie using his favorite fruit: mango! He  picked a recipe for a mango smoothie from the recipe book.

The recipe said:

“Mix milk and mango puree in the ratio 1:2.”

So, James mixed 1 cup of mango puree and 2 cups of milk, and made a mango smoothie. He then excitedly sipped some of the smoothie to taste it ... and then spat it out again.

“Eurrrgh!” James said, staring at the smoothie. “This is too milky. Did I do something wrong?”

Did James do something wrong? (And why do you think that?)

objective: Learn why the order of the numbers in a ratio is important.
title: Order is Important
